$values.value: Leaving care can be a challenging time. Whether you’re still in care or have already left, help is available.

$values.description: Who is this support for - left hand block

$values.value: Who is this support for?
You might have the right to leaving care support if you:
are aged 16 to 24
were

content.value: What does ‘looked after’ mean?
You’re ‘looked after’ if the local authority takes care of you for more than 24 hours. This can happen if:
the local authority gave you a place to stay (for example, a children’s home or emergency foster home)
a court decided that you needed to be looked after
a court decided where you must live (for example, in a foster home)
you got into trouble with the law and had to stay in a secure place (like a young offender institution or a secure children’s home)
Sometime people may call you:
child looked after or ‘CLA’ for short
‘looked after child’ or ‘LAC’ for short

$values.value: or have spent time

content.value: What does ‘in care’ mean?
If you’re in care, it means you’re a young person who is ‘looked after’ by the local authority. You might live in:
a children’s home
supported lodgings
a young offender institution
a secure children’s home
a foster home
The local authority has legal responsibility for you and must support you.
Depending on the time you were looked after for, you may have a ‘care leaver status’. Having a status gives you the right to get certain support.
Learn what the terms ‘in care’, ‘looked after’, and ‘care leaver’ mean.
Helpful links

$values.value: in England
This includes:
foster care
residential care (like a children’s home)
time in custody (like a young offender institution or secure children’s home)
if you came to seek asylum in the UK alone before 18

$values.description: Who is this support for - right hand block

target.description: Two young women sat outside at a covered table. One is holding a white mug. Both are in their coats
target.title: Two young women chatting over a hot drink

titleLocalized.en-US: Two young women chatting over a hot drink

descriptionLocalized.en-US: Two young women sat outside at a covered table. One is holding a white mug. Both are in their coats

$values.value: Find support

$values.title: Money and benefits
$values.text: Help with money when you leave care and benefits you can apply for

image.title: Money and benefits

$values.value: When you leave care, you may have the right to certain support and there’s some you must apply for.
What do you need help with?

$values.title: Housing and accommodation
$values.text: Help finding somewhere to live and other support with housing costs

image.title: Housing and accomodation

$values.value: Help with housing costs and finding somewhere to live
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Help with money
Leaving Care Allowance
Money to set up your next home (also called ‘Setting Up Home Allowance’)
Junior Individual Savings Account (ISA) (Opens in a new tab)
A bank account containing money you can get from your 18th birthday
Planning where you’ll live
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who helps you find somewhere safe to live that meets your needs
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers where you will live, including support you need
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
money off your council tax bill (council tax discount) or not paying it at all (council tax exemption)
acting as a guarantor for rent so you can live in private rented property or help with a deposit
help with housing costs like a TV licence (making you exempt from the fee), internet or utility bills (gas, electricity and water)
Find out more about Local Offers

target.title: Know what support you can get
target.text: Use your 'care leaver status' to find out what support you have the right to.

image.title: Know what support you can get

titleLocalized.en-US: Know what support you can get

$values.value: Learn about care leaver statuses and work out what support you have a right to.
What is a ‘care leaver status’?
You may have a care leaver status if you:
are aged 16 to 25
have been looked after by a local authority
Having a care leaver status gives you the right to get certain support. It helps your council understand what support they must give you.

$values.description: How to work out your status

$values.value: How to work out your status
To understand if you have a status and which one you have, you need to know:
how long you were looked after
how old you were when this happened
whether you’re still being looked after or not
If you need help working this out, you can ask:
your social worker
your
personal adviser (PA)
an independent advocate
someone else from your council
They can also help you access your records if you’re not sure about certain details.
Former relevant child
Your status is ‘former relevant child’ if you’re aged 18 to 25. When you were 16 or 17, your status was either:
relevant child
eligible child
You may get support past 25 if you started college or university full time before your 25th birthday.
See what support you have a right to if your status is
former relevant child.

$values.description: Persons qualifying for advice and assistance

$values.value: Persons qualifying for advice and assistance
Your status is a ‘person qualifying for advice and assistance’ if you’re aged 16 to 20. You were also either:
looked after by a local authority before a Special Guardianship Order was made. This order is either still in place or was in place when you were 18
looked after at some point between the ages of 16 and 18 but you are not anymore
See what support you have a right to if your status is
persons qualifying for advice and assistance
Eligible child
Your care leaver status is ‘eligible child’ if you:
are aged 16 or 17
are being looked after by a local authority
have been looked after for at least 13 weeks
The 13 weeks must:
have started after your 14th birthday
include some time after your 16th birthday
See what support you have a right to if your status is
eligible child
Relevant child
Your care leaver status is ‘relevant child’ if you:
are aged 16 or 17
are no longer being looked after by a local authority
were looked after for at least 13 weeks
The 13 weeks must:
have started after your 14th birthday
include some time after your 16th birthday
Other reasons this could be your status
Your status is relevant child if you were looked after for at least 13 weeks after your 14th birthday and then:
went into hospital after your 16th birthday
were detained after your 16th birthday (in somewhere like a young offenders institution or secure training centre)
See what support you have a right to if your status is
relevant child
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Universal Credit (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with living costs if you’re on a low income, out of work or cannot work.
Discretionary Housing Payment (DHP) (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with rent or housing costs.
Council tax support (Opens in a new tab)
Apply to your local council for a reduction on your council tax bill.

Help with money and benefits you can apply for
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Help with money
Leaving Care Allowance
Money to set up your next home (also called ‘Setting Up Home Allowance’)
Junior Individual Savings Account (ISA) (Opens in a new tab)
A bank account containing money you can get from your 18th birthday
Higher Education Bursary
Money to help you go to university or college
Apprenticeships Care Leavers’ Bursary (Opens in a new tab)
Money to help you if you're doing an apprenticeship
Managing your money
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who guides you on how to manage your money and helps you get support
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers how to manage your money and get support you need
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
money for your birthday
help paying for your driving lessons or driving test
money for living costs to cover food, travel and essential clothes
Find out more about Local Offers

include some time after your 16th birthday
Other reasons this could be your status
Your status is relevant child if you were looked after for at least 13 weeks after your 14th birthday and then:
went into hospital after your 16th birthday
were detained after your 16th birthday (in somewhere like a young offenders institution or secure training centre)
See what support you have a right to if your status is
relevant child
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Universal Credit (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with living costs if you’re on a low income, out of work or cannot work.
Personal Independence Payment (PIP) (Opens in a new tab)
To help you with living costs if you have a disability, illness or health condition and difficulties with daily living or mobility.
Discretionary Housing Payment (DHP) (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with rent or housing costs.
Council tax support (Opens in a new tab)
Apply to your local council for a reduction on your council tax bill.

$values.title: Housing and accommodation
$values.text: Help finding somewhere to live and other support with housing costs

image.title: Housing and accomodation

$values.value: Help with housing costs and finding somewhere to live
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Help with money
Leaving Care Allowance
Money to set up your next home (also called ‘Setting Up Home Allowance’)
Junior Individual Savings Account (ISA) (Opens in a new tab)
A bank account containing money you can get from your 18th birthday
Planning where you’ll live
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who helps you find somewhere safe to live that meets your needs
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers where you will live, including support you need
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
money off your council tax bill (council tax discount) or not paying it at all (council tax exemption)
acting as a guarantor for rent so you can live in private rented property or help with a deposit
help with housing costs like a TV licence (making you exempt from the fee), internet or utility bills (gas, electricity and water)
Find out more about Local Offers

target.title: Know what support you can get
target.text: Use your 'care leaver status' to find out what support you have the right to.

image.title: Know what support you can get

titleLocalized.en-US: Know what support you can get

$values.value: Learn about care leaver statuses and work out what support you have a right to.
What is a ‘care leaver status’?
You may have a care leaver status if you:
are aged 16 to 25
have been looked after by a local authority
Having a care leaver status gives you the right to get certain support. It helps your council understand what support they must give you.

$values.description: How to work out your status

$values.value: How to work out your status
To understand if you have a status and which one you have, you need to know:
how long you were looked after
how old you were when this happened
whether you’re still being looked after or not
If you need help working this out, you can ask:
your social worker
your
personal adviser (PA)
an independent advocate
someone else from your council
They can also help you access your records if you’re not sure about certain details.
Former relevant child
Your status is ‘former relevant child’ if you’re aged 18 to 25. When you were 16 or 17, your status was either:
relevant child
eligible child
You may get support past 25 if you started college or university full time before your 25th birthday.
See what support you have a right to if your status is
former relevant child.

$values.description: Persons qualifying for advice and assistance

$values.value: Persons qualifying for advice and assistance
Your status is a ‘person qualifying for advice and assistance’ if you’re aged 16 to 20. You were also either:
looked after by a local authority before a Special Guardianship Order was made. This order is either still in place or was in place when you were 18
looked after at some point between the ages of 16 and 18 but you are not anymore
See what support you have a right to if your status is
persons qualifying for advice and assistance
Eligible child
Your care leaver status is ‘eligible child’ if you:
are aged 16 or 17
are being looked after by a local authority
have been looked after for at least 13 weeks
The 13 weeks must:
have started after your 14th birthday
include some time after your 16th birthday
See what support you have a right to if your status is
eligible child
Relevant child
Your care leaver status is ‘relevant child’ if you:
are aged 16 or 17
are no longer being looked after by a local authority
were looked after for at least 13 weeks
The 13 weeks must:
have started after your 14th birthday
include some time after your 16th birthday
Other reasons this could be your status
Your status is relevant child if you were looked after for at least 13 weeks after your 14th birthday and then:
went into hospital after your 16th birthday
were detained after your 16th birthday (in somewhere like a young offenders institution or secure training centre)
See what support you have a right to if your status is
relevant child
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Universal Credit (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with living costs if you’re on a low income, out of work or cannot work.
Discretionary Housing Payment (DHP) (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with rent or housing costs.
Council tax support (Opens in a new tab)
Apply to your local council for a reduction on your council tax bill.
